We sent information to staff and families tonight about the extra work we are doing to increase wellness in our buildings, and to keep students and staff safe upon their return to school.

- Using electrostatic backpack sprayers with CDC-approved cleaners to sanitize all surfaces - including desks, chairs, doors, etc.
- Increasing the number of times high touch surfaces are sanitized each day.
- Adjusting the HVAC units at each building to bring in more fresh, outside air.
- Installing touchless paper towel dispensers.
- Adding touchless hand sanitizer stations to high traffic areas in all buildings.
- Installing plexiglass barriers at the front desk for all buildings.
- Ordering face shields and masks for staff use (delivery expected before August 15).

While these actions provide additional safety measures, using face coverings and washing our hands frequently are the best ways to prevent the spread of any illness (including COVID-19).

We are excited to announce our summer meal delivery program. That's right, meal delivery will continue through the summer!

Starting on Tuesday, May 26, we will deliver meals in each area one day each week. Families in Auburn and Eastern Montgomery will receive their meals on Tuesday, families in Blacksburg will receive meals on Wednesday, and families in Christiansburg will receive meals on Thursday.

Bus routes and drop off times will remain the same. The big difference is that meals will only be delivered on one day each week, depending on where you live. Students will receive 5 lunches on their meal delivery day.

The program is self-sustaining through the federal reimbursement program. Previously, our summer meal program has been site-based. Using our meal delivery service removes the transportation barrier so students can continue to receive meals at their homes. We know that this will be beneficial to families in our area throughout the summer months who have come to rely on the meal delivery bus to feed their families.

MCPS is proactively working to prevent the spread of respiratory viruses in our schools. All commonly-used areas (like water fountains and restrooms) are cleaned at least twice per day. Our facilities staff works hard to make sure our schools are safe and healthy.

A few suggestions to help keep our schools healthy:
- Wash your hands regularly, using soap and water, for at least 20 seconds.
- Wash cold weather gear (hats, coats, gloves, etc).
- Use disinfecting wipes to clean items that are not easily washed (cell phones, chromebooks, notebooks).
- Stay home if you are sick. Children (and adults) should stay home if they are sick and until they are fever-free for 24 hours without medication.

Two of our schools started house programs this year - Christiansburg Elementary School and Belview Elementary School. Why house programs? Houses in a school create community and unity between grade levels. They also provide students with a sense of belonging. Creating smaller communities within the school allows students to form strong bonds and connections with students and teachers they might not meet otherwise.

Are you a parent at CES or Belview? Tell us your child's house and what you like most about the house system so far!

Our first collaborative planning day for elementary and middle school teachers is tomorrow - Friday, August 30. Elementary and middle schools will dismiss 2.5 hours early. Teachers will use the time to meet by teams and/or grade level and they will plan classroom curriculum, lessons, and assessments. This time is needed for elementary and middle school teachers because they do not have built in collaborative planning time in the school day.

We try to keep our early dismissal days consistent so that they are easier for families to plan for. They are always on the last school day of the month (except for September, when we accommodate the Va Tech weekday evening game).

#ThisisMCPS #MCPSDidYouKnow
